element_texts.text: Completed

Afternoon - John 5 - 1::9.
In the introduction in reference to the times yearly feasts of the unclear - The one reformed to was probably the Pasover "A pool", - a bathing place or spring possibly medicinal qualities to which all unclear seasons great multitudes resorted to be healed of diseases -

   The unclear important --- lessons from this narration ---
          1. We see the helpless state of the sinner
          2. That ample provisions is made for their salvation-
          3. The willingness of Christ to save ---
          4. We are entirely dependent on God for aid ---
          5. It is our duty to avail ourselves of the means of grace so far as in our power, The healing stream would have been useless, had not the impotent resorted unclear ones 
              availed themselves of its virtues.
          6.If we press forward in the unclear of every duty and obey the unclear of the Savior, we shall find abundant aid will be bestowed God himself will be our helper ---

Feb. 23 - Gather.
Forenoon Rev- 15-4- "Who shall not fear thee, O Lord, and glorify thy name- Design to show why we should glorify God, and how we may glorify him.
Afternoon - John 21.15. Introduction - a statement of the manner in wh. Peter & the other disciples we employed during unclear a whole night - of Jesus' appearing to them in the morning, and directing them when they might successfully cast in their nets The impulsive, daring, Peter, is soon as he knows it was Jesus, "cast himself into the sea, and soon gained' the shore. the others come in this boat with the fishes -- After their unclear
Completed

March 2, Mr. H. Clark,
Forenson John 21.15&16.
Introduction - mentioned the circumstances under which Christ and his disciples had met. He addresses to Peter the inquiry, solemnly and earnestly, "Lovest thou me?" and after receiving his reply gives him a charge, "Feed my lambs" and "my sheep", as much as to say - If thou lovest me labor for me, do my will; minister to my unclear. This, Peter obeyed, to the end of life The apostles and many others of the early christians, literally, did what they could. They forsook houses and lands and kindred, all that was dear to them. They were cast out dispised and forsaken of men, persecuted, and driven from city to city, exposed to dangers, hardships and trials of every discription, till at last they laid down their lives even for Christ's sake. And gladly they submitted to these things, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer for Christ.
If then we truly love Christ it will lead to action, to ardent, self-denying effort to save souls. We are Christians just so far as we are like Christ. He loved to do the will of his father. It is then in vain to suppose ourselves Christians and never put forth one effort for the salvation of our fellow beings.
If we would do good we must 1. Think, seriously and deeply.
Completed

might as well talk to the tides as to address listless hearers.
6. It must be accompanied by a holy example. The fruits of the gospel should be manifest in daily life.
We learn from the subject the immense responsibility of the ambassadors of Christ. 
Afternoon, John 19.30 - "It is finished". Nothing is so solemn, so awe-striking as the contemplation of death. The last words spoken, breathed when the departing soul is just on the verge of eternity are invested with a peculiar earnestness & force, "It is finished - were the last words of the most wonderful personage who ever appeared on our earth. The dying words of the Savior of a world. They are full of meaning, we may well consider their impact. Christ was dying to redeem a lost world. Two great ideas we should ever bear in mind. 1. Mankind have sinned and are lost. 2 There is full redemption in Christ. Ruin _ Redemption are the two great ideas.
1. Consider the work of preparation for this appearance of the Messiah on Earth. (There was a unclear sketch of the worlds history designed to show that all the great events were preporatory to the one - the coming of Christ.) To show his unclear of sin God sent his judgements. He destroyed the cities of the plain, he deluged the whole earth. Then he made a covenat with the faithful Abraham, making him the father of a new nation and establishing a law by which they should be governed. But still they sinned. Then these ceremonial observances were done away and Christ came. God's will, beloved Son, and gave himself "a ransom".
2. Consider what was finished, the toils & labors, the trials and sufferings of the Savior. The great work
Completed

go to the house of God. So early that they will not remember the first time.
4. Thoroughly instruct them in the doctrines and precepts of the Bible.
5. Furnish them with suitable books, both religious and literary. Strive in every way to make home the dearest spot.
6 Keep them in evenings, except they go out by special permission, and into proper company.
7. Teach them benevolence
8. Strive to lead them to Christ.
6. It is the duty of Christians to give of their substance, to sustain the gospel at home, and in foreign lands. This makes no one poorer, for "There is that scattereth, and yet increaseth and there is that witholdeth more than is meet, and it leadeth to poverty.
(Subject - resumed in the afternoon, under a different head.)
Afternoon, Heb. 2.1,2 and part of the 3d verses.
1. A summary of what has passed unclear the year connected with the church and society. Deaths, removals, addition Progress of benevolent societies, support of one society to procure? funds to unclear a unclear Union among the members, and favorable prospect, for the support of gospel.
2. The duty of giving "heed to the things which we have heard".
3. The sin, the great sin of neglecting salvation.
Completed

believe, with our whole hearts we must love him, and, with cheerfulness, we must obey his precepts and commands. Is this a hard requisition? Do we hesitate to love and obey Him who has loved us and given himself for us?
In conclusion, have we this hope which is built on the sure foundation How important is self examination. From the heart we should offer the prayer "Lord search me and know my heart" &c
April 6. Father preached Forenoon
Afternoon. Isiah 28.16 "Therefore this saith the Lord God, Behold, I lay in unclear for a foundation, a stone, a tried stone, a precious corner stone, a sure foundation, he that believeth shall not make haste". (Not be overcome or forced to flee (as in battles))
April 13. Mr. C. Marshall. 
Gen. 5.24 - "And Enoch walked with God". This is a strong expression, denoting the devotion of Enoch to the service of God and close communion with him in wh. he lived. How comprehensive, how full of meaning are the few words - "walked with God".
1. Consider the practicableness of thus, walking with God.
2. The means by wh. we may do this.
3. The hinderances we meet in accomplishing the work.
4. The blessedness of walking with God.
Completed

the despair of the unclear soul in the world of woe, will be the thought that he might have enjoyed the bliss of heaven forever, instead of never ending misery in hell. Some plead as an excuse for neglecting the soul that they are unable, the decrees of God prevent them. Let such remember that men too make decrees, and see to it that they seal not their own destruction. 
April 20, Father
Text in Luke 12. 1=2
Christ was a wonderful preacher, he truly "spake as never man spake". At the time referred to in the text he was surrounded by a vast concourse of people, yet he hesitated not plainly and pointedly to tell them this truth with unclear to the Pharisees, and warn them to beware of their doctrine.
This aim was not to utter words wh. should fall pleasantly upon the ears of the people, but to proclaim God's truth whatever might oppose.
The Pharisees were a sect among the Jews who were distinguished for their hypocritical worship. They enlarged the borders of their garment, made broad their phylacteries, prayed unclear in the corners of the streets, to be seen of men, loved the chief seats in the synagogues, and greetings in the markets, and to be called of men
Completed

gladly fly, on swiftest wing to hover over the child of God and speak peace and joy to the unclear heart. But their joy is greatest when an "heir of glory" is born, when a sinner turns from sin to holiness. Then their golden harps are tuned to loudest, sweetest strains. State some reasons for this joy 1. Give reason unclear in the intellectual nature of angels. 2. Care? is found in the social nature of angels. 3. It glorifies God, as well as redeems a sinner from death. Whatever glorifies God caused the angels to rejoice, and all heaven to be filled with gladness 4. The object of Christ's death is accomplished. 
Reflections, 1. How great is the work of conversion! Angels in heaven rejoice over one sinner that repents. Then should not man rejoice & praise the Savior's name? A soul loved! redeemed from endless misery! There? worthy praise, throughout the universe 2. unclear see the importance of laboring for souls, let others seek for fame, for worldly honor and renown, for wealth and station high, for what a king would call a crown but be it ours to seek the honor wh God gives the faithful christian, the
Completed

unclear to the teachings of conscience. 2 It is contrary to the Spirits dictates. 3 Contrary to God's will as revealed in his word.
4 Contrary to the object which all have in view, the pursuit of happiness. There is no true happiness out of Christ, and virtuous path. "But wisdoms ways are ways of pleasantness and all her paths are peace."
May 11. Rev. Mr. Holmes preached in Westboro' Class.
Text in Forenoon Isiah 62.10. Afternoon Lev. 19-33:34, and Deut. 10-17,18,19.
Completed

June 8, 1857. Rev. Mr unclear from N. York Agent for the the "American & Foreign Christian Union".
Preached through the day from the first verse of the sixth chapter of Galatians, "Brethren, if a man be overtaken in a fault, ye which are spiritual, restores" &c
The Romish and Greek churches represent the "brother overtaken in a fault." It is the duty of "those which are spiritual" or whom God has saved from error to restore as far as in their power, God helping them these fallen churches. They were once the true church, to whom the Apostles and Christ himself preached. 
At one time it seemed as if the Romish power would annihilate true Christianity; reference to the thirty years war and the victorious army of the Swedish prince, Gustavas Adolphus. Since this, until very recently the feeling has seemed to exist that to convert Romanists would be a hopeless undertaking. But it is found they may be affected by the truth. Their affection must be won, their confidence secured, and they will listen (reference to the labors of Dr. Calla on the island of Madere among the Portuguese - also reference to the state of things in Italy, at Rome French bayonets restored the Pope, and they alone retain him in his position. 1500 States, in N. York, not one is at heart a Romanist. The death blow has been given to Popery at Rome, and its foundations tremble through the world.
A chapel called the American Protestant Chapel is located at Rome, Mr Cass the chaplain, ministers of every denomination there proclaim the gospel. It is a Protestant Chapel, not denominational
Completed

receive provide of God, and be admitted to his own he overly home, to share his love forever. Afternoon, John 3=19.20.21, 
"And this is the condemnation, that light is come into the world and men loved &c."
June 22. Father preached,
Solomon's Song 6.3, "I am my beloved's and my beloved is mine".
This illustrates the intimate union between Christ and his church. Propose to consider some of the evidences of union to Christ. 
1. True humility is an evidence of true pity.
2. Pleasure in communion with God, or delight in prayer.
3. Love of the Scriptures, where God has revealed his will to his creatures. 
4. Increasing pleasure in contemplating the character and glorious perfections of God.
5. Love of holiness whereas it is discovered to exist. The humblest disciple of Jesus is dear to the christians heart, because like Jesus.
6. An increasing sense of our own guilt, and hatred to sin
7. Constant desire to do good to our fellow beings, to labor for Jesus.
Completed

out and he was plucked from the burning, saved forever. Thanks be to a merciful God! The christian is under everlasting obligation to heaven for his unclear. A great weight of responsibility is resting upon him. I am he wh. has himself been plucked from the burning be indifferent while those about him, perhaps in his own family circle, born of his born and flesh of his flesh, are still under the power of sin: If God has mercifully rescued us from this consuming fire how zealous should we be in endeavoring to save others from the same destruction which threatened us!
The blood of Jesus alone is effectual in quenching the fires of sin.
Afternoon, Luke 23.34 Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do. First a brief statement of the circumstances in which these words were uttered. They Savior was already nailed to the cross, the cruel irons were driven into his hands and feet and the spear had pierced his side, with his bloody persecutors all about him rejoicing in the belief that their wicked designs were nearly accomplished Jesus spoke in the language of the text "Father forgive them for they know not what they do".
Completed

Father preached. July 27. 1. Chron, 16. 29. "Give unto the Lord the glory due unto his name."
Afternoon, Psalm 25. 1-2. "Unto thee, O' Lord, do I lift up my soul. O my God, I trust in thee." 
Lightening struck Mr. Colby's house July 27.3
Aug 3, Father.
Forenoon, Psalms 10.16, "The Lord is King forever and ever, the heathens are perished out of his land".
Afternoon, John 3.3. Subject, the nature and importance of regeneration. It consists not in a physical change or a change of the intellectual powers, but of the affections of the heart. Sin is not a physical malady. Were it such, it would require a physical change. Regeneration is important because it is essential to repentance - without it we cannot have true love to God, nor can we as all be prepared for the pleasures and employments of Heaven.
Aug. 24, Father preached.
Forenoon from James 2.17. "Even so, faith, if it have not works, is dead, being alone." Subject was the importance of manifesting faith by works.
1. It is important because not thus to manifest faith proves it to be spurious. True faith will be displayed in the life.
2. The honor of God demands it.
3. It is for the glory of Religious, the cause of Christ demands it.
Completed

pented the Lord that he had made man upon the earth.
Object of the discourse to reconcile these apparently opposing declarations of God's word.
1. Consider what is implied in repentance. 1. A change of heart purpose. 2 A change of heart. 3 A change of personal? conduct, as a fruit.
2. Consider in what sense God does not repent. He does not change his purpose. He does not change his heart. 3. In what sense does he repent? but He changes in relation to his external action on the dealings of his Providence. He only seems to man to repent It is in this sense only that the term can be applied.
We find illustrations of God's change of providence or treatment of man in the case of the antediluvians, Pharaoh, the cities of unclear and Gomorrah?, and the rebellious Israelites.
This subject shows
1. The wisdom of trusting and obeying God. He is the same yesterday, today and forever.
2. It shows the folly of forgetfulness of God, and disobedience to his commands.
Sept. 7. Mr. Mills from Crawforddwills? Preached from Numbers 32.23. "Be sure your sin will find you out". Afternoon, Communion service.
Completed

regarded him with the highest reverence now despised him. (Shimei cursed.)
5. Loss of God's sensible presence.
2. Show how in such trials the sent? of the true saint should not be cast down but trust in God. David himself asks reproachfully "Why art thou cast down, O my soul, and why art thou disquieted within me. Hope thou in God" &c.
We may find a sanctuary, a mercy seat even in the wilderness and God will dwell with us and hear the hunrk? fervent prayer.
If friends prove faithless God is ever true. He is a unclear to all who trust in him. If earthly possessions and honors fail there is an inheritance in heaven that will endure forever and honors such as the world may not boast honors that come from the sovereign of the universe. 
And then if God hides his face and his presence seems departed his precious promise is "For a small moment have I forsaken them &c.
In view of this let us, with the pious Psalmist rejoice in God.
Oct. 5. Uncle Rufus Putnam Rom. 14:9 and Matthew 25:1-13.
Completed

2. Why should we rejoice with trembling
1. We are liable to self decepion. We may be travelling the broad road to death and still think ourselves safe in Jesus' fold. How much then we need to be watchful and prayerful and fear. unclear we fail of the grace of God.
2. If we are really renewed, we are liable to back unclear and reproach the cause we profess to love. Then surely if we rejoice at all we have abundant cause to tremble too. This subject should inspire us with faith in God. We must trust in him alone. Of ourselves we are nothing.
Oct. 26. Father unable to preach
Nov. 2. Father preached, Matt 26.41. Watch and pray that ye enter not into temptation. Rom. 8; 1-9. There is therefore now no condemnation &c.
Attended, Nov. 5., a missionary meeting at Concord at which Mr. Goodell and Dr. Powry? were present & by this remarks rendered the exercises exceedingly interesting. Mr. Goodell has been 29 years a laborer, first at unclear then at Malta and his present station is Constantinople among Armenland Greeks and Turks During these years he had packed his goods and moved 33 times in consequence of war, persecution, conflagration, plague &c. Now houses are built of stone, prevents so frequent unclear; quarantine unclear establish
Completed

their brother Lazarus lived, and where Jesus loved to go, or a pomegranate from the fields of Boaz, or a willow or a pebble from the banks of Jordan. But though unclear never visited these interesting places we have been engaged in a great and noble work. We have been transplanting precious flowers into the garden of the Lord to floors? forever there I should love to walk where Jesus walked, to stand where he stood and weep where he weep, but I felt that my time was not my own, and that all I had must be devoted to Jesus, and not spent in gratifying my own desires.
(Names at Constantinople. Miss Morning unclear Assistant teacher in the school for girls. Miss Good Works, Miss Wisdom married unclear Glad unclear Mr. Resurrection a native preacher.)
Nov. 5. Father preached. 
Luke 5.11. And they forsook all and followed him.
Prov. 29.1. He that, being often reproved, hardwith? his neck, shall suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy.
Nov. 23. Father preached
Rom. 7; 10-11. "And the commandment which was ordained to life I found unclear". Col. 2:10. "And ye are complete in him which is the head of all principality and power".
Theme - Those who receive Christ, will have their highest want completely supplied.
Consider man's wants
The fact that those who receive
Completed

Do we need saving knowledge? Christ can impart it. He is the medium of of communication between God and fallen man. The word was made flesh and dwelt among us.
Do we need justifying righteousness? Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth. Do we need the aids of the Holy Spirit? Christ had promised his followers that he will send them the comforter, which is the Holy Spirit.
Do we need an Almighty Friend? Christ is such. He has promised his followers he will never leave nor forsake them. He has all power in heaven and on earth.
Do we need a home in Heaven? Christ had said, "In my Father's house are many mansions. I go to prepare a place for you, that where I am there you may be also."
Nov. 30. (Father)
Math. 22: 11,12. "And when the king came in to see the guests, he saw there a man which had not on a wedding garment". "And he saith unto him, Friend, how camest thou in hither, not having a wedding garment? And he was speechless."
Job. 22 : 21. Acquired now thyself with him, and be at peace; therely
Completed

1. He should become acquainted with God now, because he has commanded it. Now is the accepted time. He have no promise of further opportunity.
2. Because in so doing we secure to ourselves a vast amount of the highest enjoyment. We are admited to the presence chamber of the King of the Universe, our joys are such as earth cannot bestow, and cannot remove.
3. By delay, the soul, the precious souls may be eternally lost. O, how many souls have been received by delay! Forget not the words of the text, "Acquaint now thyself with him and be at peace; therely good shall come unto thee".
Dec. 7. 1857, Father preached
Job. 23. 12. "I have esteemed the words of his mouth more than my necessary food."
There. The value of good word to the true believer. Consider why it should be precious
Completed

He who plunders his neighbors dwelling may be unclear and unclear but this does not save from imprisonment, Neither does the penitence of the murderer save from the gallows. Very little heed would be given to the law which pardoned the penitent transgressor on the ground of his repentance. 
3. There must be an atonement or the sinner must perish. This atonement has been made The Lord of the universe has given his own Son to die as a Sacrifice to atone for sin that the transgressor may live. But 
4. The sinner must accept of the conditions of the atonement in order to be justified and saved. Who will reject a proffered Savior who despise salvation offered by the God of Heaven? Who refuse to love with the whole heart so precious a Redeemer! He has purchased us with his own blood and should not our all be his.
Afternoon Math. 16. 25. "And whosoever will lose his life for my sake shall find it." (& unclear and Cardinal unclear referred to as examples in opposition to each other.)
Completed

5. Hatred to sin, and a strong desire to be holy like God.
The true Christian longs to be free from sin, and to become more & more like his Father in Heaven. He ardently desires Gods presence, dwelling ever in his inmost soul.
Have we these evidences of union of Christ? The subject should lead to strict self-examination. Afternoon. Matt 12:13 "Then saith we to the man, Stretch forth thy hand And he stretched forth, and it was restored whole, like as the other."
Illustrated first the difference between natural and moral inability by several examples of both. 
In the case mentioned in the text is a matured inability. There is a want of physical power. The sinner when called upon to comply with the conditions of salvation has moral inability. He is indisposed to obey.
1. All men are affected with a grievous malady. Sin corrupted their whole nature, from the sole of the foot to the crown of the head they are covered with wounds and bruises and putrefying sores. They have no soundness.
2. They cannot have themselves but are entirely dependent on
Completed

Jan 9, 1851, Father preached.
Forenoon, 2. Cor. 4. 11.
1. Consider the prominent unclear which adorned the Savior's character.
1. Humility. 2. Patience. 3. Devotedness. 4. unclear and Firmness. 5. Prayerfulness.
2. The importance of imitating these.
Afternoon. Galatians. 4. 18. 
1. The nature of true zeal.
1. It springs from knowledge.
2. It is induced by good motives of heart.
3. It is divided in the right way to the accomplishment of the best ends
2. It is the duty of everyone to posses true zeal for God. Every Christian should be active in laboring for God. Soon the night will come and no more opportunity be afforded to co-operate with God in the glorious work of the world's conversion.
Jan. 16. (Father)
Forenoon Psalm 119. 129. "Thy testimonies are wonderful." The bible is a wonderful book not only because of it's Author but because of the contents. The doctrines it reveals the precepts it (contains) enforced, the history it discloses all are wondrous. It tells us of the character of God, "glorious in holiness fearful in praises, doing wonders". It also tells us the character of man, naturally sinful, totally depraved, wholly opposed to all that is good and holy. 
Many efforts have been made to destroy the Bible, to banish it entirely from the world, but it has stood, while empires and kingdoms have fallen. Those nations which obeyed its precepts have been blessed and prosperous, while those who neglected it and affected to despise its precepts, have felt God's just displeasure and in some instances been entirely overthrown. It is to the Bible that this people owe their prosperous and happy state. Shall we not then scatter to the world, those unclear wh. shall for this healing of the nations let us do with our mi
Completed

An unclear We must labor and give
repast, "Jesus said to Simon Peter, "Simon Son of Jonas, lovest thou me more than these. After receiving his reply "Yes, Lord, thou knowest that I love thee", Jesus again put the question, and received a like reply. unclear saith unto him the third time "Simon Son of Jonas, lovest thou me?" "Peter was grieved because he said unto him the third time, Lovest thou me? And he said unto him, Lord, thou knowest all things, thou knowest that I love thee".
The question thus addressed by our Lord to his disciple, was full of solemn meaning, and is no less so at the present time. In order fully and clearly to understand its import, we may consider.
1. The nature of true love to our Savior.
1. It is the love of complacency. We should love Christ for what he is in himself. Because we see and feel that he is indeed pure and good "glorious in holiness", infinitely worthy our highest adoration, and our trust, purest, love.
2. It is disinterested.
3. It is supreme. It fills all our being.
4. It is action. It will lead us to devote our whole life to His service, who alone is worthy our supreme affection, cheerfully we shall labor for Him, if we truly love Him.
2. Consider the importance of exercising this love.
1. It is the foundation of all moral excellence. All else is as "sounding frass", or a tinkling symbol."
2. It makes us like God.
3. It is the only thing that can fill us for the endless bliss of Heaven.
How infinitely important then that we possess this love. It should actuate every act of our life, and animate every hope. Without it we perish eternally. We learn, hence, the duty of rigid self-examination.
Completed

And 2. We must labor, and give of our substance, as God hath prospered us.
3. We must pray. We must pray much, that God would prosper our endeavors. Without His favor, all is vain. Afternoon, Communion Season.
March 9, 1851. (Mr. Leonard Parker)
Forenoon. Mathew 7. 29. "For he taught them as one having authority and not as the Scribes." These words are found at the close of the Sermon on the Mount, where the feelings of the people are described, with refer? to the instructions they had been receiving. They "were astonished at His doctrine". His words had not been without effect. 
It was proposed to consider some things which are essential to the under human teaching effective 
1. To render human teaching effectual it must be in accordance with God's Word. 
2. The truths of God's Word must be presented in proportion. Some minds delight to dwell on the mysteries of the Bible, its curious points. They value it for the historical knowledge, or for the many variations of intellect displayed. They lose sight of the peace of redemption therein revealed. They forget the words of Christ, "What shall it profit a man if he gain the whole world, & lose his own soul?
3. There should be an adaptation of this unclear truths to the various necessities and circumstances of our fellow beings. "A word, fitly spoken, is like apples of gold, in pictures of silver." To be able thus to apply God's truth requires a most thorough acquaintance with the Bible, accompanied with constant prayerfulness and untiring effort.
4. The truth must be presented with (earnestness), and (seriousness), and emotion.
5. It must be addressed to the consciousness of men. No preaching will prove effectual unless conscience is unclear A minister
Completed

of redemption was accomplished." His unclear the wine press alone". Of his disciples one had betrayed him, the others had fled, and even the Father's face was veiled. Oh the agony He endured! And all for our sins! But it is finished, and He reigns triumphant in heaven, our risen, our ascended Savior. And still He intercedes "for those whose sins he bore" can any but love Him?
March 16, Concord N. H.
Forenoon, Mr Bouton from John 6.37, "And him that cometh to me, I will in no wise cast out".
Afternoon, Mr. Glanders from Matt. 6.33, "But seek ye first the kingdom of God and his righteousness, and all these things shall be added unto you".
March 23, Concord N. H. Mr Bouton, 26th Anniversary sermon, from Col. 1.10
Consider some things important to promote true spirituality in the church. 1. They must be united. 2 They must be pure, that the world may not point in derision to any member, as a unclear to the cause of Christ. 3. Fervent prayer and active labor. The true disciple will work for his Master. 4. Reverence for the Sabbath. 5. Regular attendance on all religious meetings during the week as well as on Sabbath. No trifle should detain. A few clouds, a chilling wind or the hot sun of summer, these do not keep me from worldly business with should they from the Sabbath holy observance. 6. Proper discharge of family duties. And 1. Family prayer should be maintained. 2. Children should be dedicated to God in baptism. 3. They should early be accustomed to
Completed

March 30, Dunbartow?. Father preached.
Forenoon. Titus 3. 5. "Not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to his mercy he saved us by the washing of regeneration and renewing of the Holy Ghost."
Afternoon, Rom. 5. 4. "And patience experience, and experience hope." The word hope constituted the theme of the discourse. There are two kinds of hope. The hope of the hypocrite, which perisheth, and the hope which is an anchor to the soul sure and steadfast. It is of infinite importance that our hope be grounded upon the sure foundation. It is useless to trust for salvation upon -
1. Amiable qualities. The young man mentioned in the gospel was alluded to as an example, God looks at the heart.
2. The strictest observance of any ceremonial code will not save up. Reference here to the Catholic Church.
3. A connection with the visible church is insufficient.
4. It is not enough that our understand assents to the doctrines of God's word
5. We must not trust for salvation to the indiscriminate mercy of God. Though provision is made to love the world yet justice will punish the guilty. The sinner deserves God's wrath for rejecting this terms of salvation.
The only real ground of hope is in Christ. In him we must
Completed

A quotation was introduced from the life of Pres. Edwards illustrating the joy he had in thinking of God, sometimes it seemed to absord his whole being, so that he seemed swallowed up in God. What an exalted happiness! How unlike earth's joys. 
We all may and should attain this blessedness.
Afternoon.
Hosea 13.2 "O Israel, thou hast destroyed thyself". This is a fearful truth; not only as applied to Israel, but to every sinner. It we perish, we ourselves alone are blameworthy. There is but one being in the universe who can ruin us, with our own selves rests this responsibility. There is but one being who can make provision for our eternal salvation, that being, God, and the provision, he has made. God then, is not chargable with the last sinner's destruction. All that could be done to secure salvation has been done. In the world of despair the sinner cannot plead as an excuse that no warning had been given of the transgression's award. The bible describes it as "outer darkness", "blackness of darkness". The remorse there experienced is described as "the worm that never dies". The most appalling images are used to describe the horrors of the world of woes.
The strongest possible motives are employed to induce the sinner to lay up a treasure in heaven. He has no excuse. One of the principal elements in
Completed

Rabbi. But they were like "whited sepulchers", there hearts were full of wickedness.
Mention some particulars in wh. the doctrine of the Pharisees was deficient. 1. Faith was defective unclear was not the faith "which works by love and purifies the heart", it began & ended in selfishness.
2. Their morality was not pleading to God since it consisted chiefly in a strict observance of outward ceremonies. There was no heart in it.
3. They depended not on Christ to save them but on their own good deeds, and they seemed to have not one doubt of their acceptance with God on this ground of their own merits. In view of this we see that self-complacency is no ground of piety. Though one may stand high in his own opinion, God look within and may view the character in an entirely different light. How then should we search our own hearts and plead with God to search us lest we be deceived. "Let him that thinketh he standeth take heed lest he fall".
Again we learn that many in the last day will be disappointed in their expectations of salvation.

Angels are interested in the transactions of earth, one part of their duty is to minister to the saints, and they

crown of glory wh fadeth never. "They that turn many to righteousness, shall shine as the stars, and as the brightness of the firmament for ever and ever." Angels shall be their companions, even in this world.
April 27, My father.
Text in Jer. 31:20. "20 Ephraim my dear son? is unclear pleasant child? for since I spake against him, I do earnestly remember him still; therefore my bowels are troubled for him; I will surely have mercy on him, saith the Lord". By Ephraim is meant the whole Israelitish nation, and the verse exhibits in a striking light the compassion and tender mercy of God towards his erring children. "For since I spoke against him I do earnestly remember him still". O how full of love! Consider 1 The strengths of God's love to his creatures. 2. This desire for their salvation. He gave his only begotten son. Think of a parents tender feeling towards the child he loves, his only one, and we may in some measure appreciate the sacrifice. 3 Consider the fact that, notwithstanding God's love sinners must be lost unless they accept of the proffered terms of salvation, God's hatred of sin is as great as his love of holiness, some reject salvation for the very simplicity of its terms at last God will reject them.

May 18, 1851. (Boston) Mr. George Hill preached in Roxbury from the text "Wilt thou be made whole" John 5.6. (In Mr. Thompson's church.)
Afternoon, Dr. Ide of Philadelphia from Acts. 27.2. 2-25 & 31. We may look to God for deliverance in times of trouble when we employ with all our might the means he has provided for our comfort and support.
May 25, 1857. Mr. Parker of Concord. Forenoon Text in Psalms 87.7 "All my springs are in thee". How sweet the thought. How desirable that every one be able to adopt the language of the pious and devoted Psalmist. "All my springs are in thee" - in God - the only fountain of all good.

(1. Consider how God spoke to his people under the old dispensation. 2 How, under the new. 3. That who under the old dispensation, disregarded God's voice perished without mercy. 4. Those who now refuse to obey his voice will receive a far more terrible doom, they are more enlightened will receive a proportionaly greater punishment.

Here is openend a vast field for Christian effort, and the disciples of Jesus should rejoice and praise God that they may have the privilege of working for him and aiding, with the means he has bestowed to carry forward this missionary enterprise. We should "do with our might" and thank heaven for every call to benevolence.

Math. 6. 3d and 4th verses. "But when thou doest alms let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth; That thine alms may be in secret; and thy Father which seeth in secret himself shall reward the openly".
Charity, benevolence, should be a ruling principle of every heart, sincere love to our fellow beings should prompt over every act.
1. Consider the nature of real charity. There is a vast difference between true charity, and that which only seems to be. The christian desires to be benevolent and kind while the worldling only desires to seem so.
Affectation always blunders - sincere feeling, never.

July 6. Father preached.
July 13. Mr Merrill from Pembroke. Amos 4. 11. Ye were as a firebrand plucked out of the burning."
This language is a figurative representation of the Christian's state. Every christian might before conversion have been likened to a firebrand, which while it destroyes, is itself destroyed. Sin is the consuming fire. The firebrand, when placed in favorable circumstances may produce a vast conflagration and destroy a large amount of property. It may be placed in a situation in which it will only consume itself. So the sinner, one sinner, may beside being himself destroyed, effect the everlasting ruin of others. The christian is as a firebrand plucked from the burning. The fire of sin was consuming him but the hand of God was stretched
Completed

They knew not what they did. They saw not the depth of their crime and its enormous wickedness. No sinner sees his guilt in its true light; does not feel the depth of his sin, nor does he feel how terrible is the wrath of God which rests upon him, as long as he loves sin.
We can see some thing of the wickedness of sin when we look at the effects of it in the world. It brings want and woe sickness, poverty, and pain and at last it takes even life away. Sinners know not what they do when they delay repentance. The burden of crime is constantly accumulating, and God's displeasure increasing. He knows not the guilt of rejecting salvation purchased with the blood of Gods eternal son; else would he fly without delay to the only refuge. 
Mr Mallace, Manchester, July 20.

Psalm 42:6. O my God, my soul is cast down within me. 
1. Consider some things which tended greatly to cast down the soul of the devout David, at the time when the language of the text was uttered.
1 Loss of sanctuary privileges. He says "My soul thirsteth for thee; my flesh longeth for thee in a dry and thirsty land where no water is, to see thy power and thy glory, so as I have seen thee in the sanctuary".
2. The treachery of his friends. Absalom and Ahithophel in particular, the former his own beloved son, the latter his prince minister and chief counsellor.
3. Loss of earthy possessions. He is described as going up Mt. Clevet, his head covered with sackcloth, barefoot and weeping, without even means of satisfying the demands of hunger.
4. Loss of worldly honors. Those who had
Completed

Oct. 12. Psalm 119:139. "My zeal hath consumed me, because mine enemies have forgotten thy words." Zeal for God and for his glory. The real disciple of Jesus is full of grief when beholding the enemies of God forgetful of his commands and despising reproof, rushing headlong down to death. Design of the discourse to show why good men thus grieve at the transgressions of the wicked. They love the law of God and earnestly desire to see all about them respecting and obeying it.
They know too, that to disregard the law of God will prevent happiness here. They love their fellow men, and grieve to see them pursuing? a course which is certain misery for this world. More than this they know that a life of sin will lead inevitably to ruin in a coming world. They love of souls in induces them to plead with the ungodly to receive Christ.
Do we grieve as did pious David over the carelessness and the danger of the unpenitent about us? Why do we not pray more; cry mightily unto God to save them. "The pervert, effectual prayer of the righteous man availeth much.
Psalm. 2. 1. "Serve the Lord with fear and rejoice with trembling".
1. Why should we serve God with fear
1. Because he is omnicient, he knoweth every false way. I? God is omnipotant. He is not only merciful but just and he is able to execute his decrees. His arm faileth not for lack of strength.

protecting from plague, and the Christian religion is protected by established law, so that there is no persecution. There was a time when those who acknowledged Christ must do it with the loss of all things literally. The goods of a merchant were thrown into the streets and himself not permitted to lay his finger on a s single article while the rabble plundered all -- they were turned out of their own houses into the street, and not even permitted to remain there, but cast into prisons and loathsome dungeons affording no place to sit in, no place to stand up in, or to lie down in; where they must every moment be suffering, and tortured with pain. For Jesus' sake they bore all, and now brighter days have dawned upon these faithful followers of Christ. They now enjoy their religion unmolested. And they are faithful still  - they have come out of fiery trials strengthened and purified. Mr. G. said he had never visited the holy city, Jerusalem. It would have been pleasant, said he, could I tell you I had stood on Mount Zion, that my feeet had trodded Mt. Christ will have them completely supplied.
I Consider man's wants.
1. Saving knowledge. Man has knowledge by which he can make the rivers his road and the ocean his highway He can measure the distance to the sun and the stars, and make the lightening of heaven do his bidding, he can weigh the hills in scales and the mountains in a balance. He has powers which fit him to be a companion of angels, and yet he needs that knowledge which, will save the soul. All else is vain.
2. Man needs justifying righteousness. No man can obtain this by his own merits.
3. He needs the aids of the Holy Spirit.
4. He needs an Almighty Friend to protect him against the evils wh. encompass him.
5 Man wants a home in heaven. We know how dear is an earthly home and how we pity the homeless wanderer. No home in all the wide unfriendly world! Well may we love our earthly home, but we need a home beyond the skies, when the turmoil of life shall be past.
I I Consider the fact that those who receive Christ will have every wants completely supplied.
Completed

good shall come unto thee".
I Show what is implied in a saving acquaintance with God.
I I Why should we now seek to become savingly acquainted with our Maker.
I Show what is implied unclear.
1. We must have some conception of his infinite power. In this he differs from the heathen deities, they are mere stumps or stones, powerless and lifeless. But who can resist Jehovah's might? This people may say, "The Lord is my strength and my shield; he is the saving strength of his anointed".
2. Some conception of his omnipresence The gods of the heathen must remain where they are placed, but the Christian's God is everywhere. This presence pervades the memberless worlds that roll in their vast orbits through the regions of infinite space.
3. We must know that he is holy.
4. That he hates sin. This very love of holiness teaches this. He is just and he will punish the transgression
5. We must love the character of God and approve of all his attributes and perfections
6. We must cordially acquiescer in his plans, and accept his terms of salvation.
I I. Why should we now &c.

Dec. 21. (Father)
Forenoon from Job. 24.4. "How then can man be justified with God". 
1. He cannot be justified on the ground that he has not sinned, for all have sinned.
2 Not because he does not now sin for he is constantly transgressing. unclear is a sinner while life endures. None are fully sanctified till removed from earth
3. Man cannot be justified because of his repentance. That government would be very weak if not wholly powerless which forgave the transgressor on the ground of his repentance.
Completed

Dec. 28, 1857.
Forenoon text in Psalms 11.4. "The Lord is in his Holy Temple, the Lord's throne is in heaven; his eyes behold, his eyelids try the children of men".
Consider some evidences by which we must try ourselves, to know whether indeed we are true disciples of Jesus
1. The true christian loves all in whom he sees the image of his divine master and loves them because they are like Jesus. "We know", says the apostle "that we have passed from death unto life, because we love the brethren. He that loveth not his brother abideth in death".
2. A feeling of good will towards all men, is requisite to even towards our enemies. In this we have our Savior's example. He died for sinners, for those even who were his murderers. It was love and good will to all which led him to give his life to save poor ruined man.
3. Delight in the character of God & in communion with him is an evidence of christian character. We must love to go to God and tell him our need, and our sorrows, and joys, as to a dearly loved friend.
4. The christian loves God's word. It is his daily meditation. He "longs for its precepts". They are his meat and drink, says the Psalmist "How sweet are thy words unto my taste! Yea, sweeter than honey to my mouth."
Completed

God to aid them. Christ is the only physician of the sin-sick soul.
3. The sinner, notwithstanding his dependence on God must put forth voluntary action in order to be saved. Had not the withered arm been stretched forth it would not have been restored. In the very effort to raise it, strength came. As soon as he made the attempt to obey the command of Jesus power was given him to raise his arm, and "it was restored whole, like the other". So, the sinner has a part to perform in procuring his own salvation. We can do nothing of ourselves, but God worketh in us, and will grant all needed aid.
Completed

Concord, Jan, 25, 1845
This may certify that the Bearer, Miss Antoinette B. Putnam, has been a private Pupil in our family and afterwards a member of the Female Seminary under our instruction, and in point of scholarship she was considered first in the several studies in which she was engaged.
In her moral & religious deportment, as well as in her studies, she exhibited a maturity and strength of mind far beyond her years. Believing her to possess in an eminent degree, all the essential qualifications requisite for a good instruction, we cheerfully reccommend her a deserving the confidence of any who may need her services.
Martha M. Haven,
Ann. M. Chadbourne
From an intimate acquaintance with Miss Antoinette & knowledge of her literary attainments. I cordially write with the above, and add my testimonial, more particularly as to her maturity of intellect & consistent moral and religious deportment.
Thomas Chadbourne
Completed

To the Friends of Education.
The bearer of this is Miss Antoinette B. Putman of Dunbarton N. H., who is one of the first class of teachers sent out by the Board of National Popular Education in Ohio.
She came to my care recommended by her clergyman as an exemplary member of the congregational church. She also brought high recommendations from her own former teachers, and also from persons who have employed her as a teacher. Since she has been under my care, I have taken pains to ascertain her qualifications, and I consider her as prepared to teach in the common branches and also in the higher English branches ordinarily pursued in our best Academics. She is also prepared to teach French and Drawing.
During the month spent here, she has had daily access to the State Normal School and its Experimental Schools, and has attended a course of Lectures on the details of teaching the elementary branches, delivered by Mr Page, the Principal, expressly for the benefit of our teachers. She has also attended an uncommonly superior course of Lectures on History, and has received a course of instruction on Physiology and the care of health. She has also been taught a system of Calisthenic exercises united with music, and lastly, has received a course of instructions from me on many topics connected with her future duties. 
I consider Miss Putnam as fully qualified, both morally and intellectually, for any position that may be assigned her, and I commend her to the kindness and care of my friends
Completed

and the friends of the patriotic cause to which she is devoted. I especially ask the sympathy, counsel and aid of the ministers of Jesus Christ, wherever she may meet them, and commend her to the special watch and care of the minister of the church with which I trust she will connect herself, as soon as her permanent location is determined. 
Catharine E. Beecher,
Albany, May 30, 1847.
